column1:
Clinical Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted for confidentiality]

Date of Discharge: [Date]

Current Status: The patient was discharged from our facility today after completing their treatment plan.

Medical History:
The patient was admitted with a history of [insert condition related to ICD-10 code 0WQF0ZZ, e.g., "complex wound care" or "venous ulcer management"]. During their stay, we provided intensive wound care and management of pressure ulcers. The patient made significant progress in healing and was able to return home with a plan for ongoing care.

Allergies:
The patient has [insert any allergies or sensitivities].

Medications:
The patient is currently taking the following medications: [list all current medications, including dosages and frequencies]. It is essential that the patient adheres to their medication regimen as directed by their healthcare provider.

Procedures:
During their stay, the patient underwent [insert procedure related to ICD-10 code 07B50ZX, e.g., "debridement" or "wound excision"]. The procedure was performed to promote wound healing and manage infection.

Lab Results:
The patient's laboratory results indicate [insert lab result related to ICD-10 code E66.3, e.g., "normal liver function tests" or "elevated white blood cell count"]. These results will be closely monitored during the patient's follow-up appointments.

Immunizations:
The patient received [insert any immunizations or vaccinations].

Follow-Up Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow up with their primary care provider within [timeframe, e.g., "2 weeks"] to monitor their condition and adjust their treatment plan as needed. Additionally, the patient should schedule regular follow-up appointments with their wound care specialist to ensure optimal healing and management of their wound.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to [insert discharge instructions related to ICD-10 code Z87.891, e.g., "keep the wound clean and dry" or "apply topical antibiotics as directed"]. It is essential that the patient follows these instructions to promote healing and prevent complications.

Special Considerations:
The patient has a history of [insert condition related to ICD-10 code C50.911, e.g., "chronic kidney disease" or "hypertension"]. The patient's healthcare provider will closely monitor their renal function and blood pressure during follow-up appointments.

Additional Notes:
The patient has been diagnosed with [insert condition related to ICD-10 code K42.9, e.g., "cancer" or "neurological disorder"]. Further testing and evaluation may be necessary to determine the cause of this condition.

The patient's vital signs are stable, and they are in no acute distress. The patient is advised to contact their healthcare provider immediately if they experience any symptoms such as fever, chills, or increasing pain.

Please note that the above summary does not include specific ICD-10 codes but rather provides a general overview of the patient's conditions and treatment plan.

column1:
**Clinical Discharge Summary**

This summary is intended to provide a concise and understandable overview of the patient's medical history, current condition, and any relevant procedures or treatments received during their hospital stay. Please note that specific ICD-10 codes used in this report have been omitted for confidentiality and clarity purposes.

**Chief Complaint:**
The patient presented with [insert chief complaint or initial reason for admission].

**Medical History:**
The patient has a history of [insert relevant medical conditions, e.g., hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus]. They were also diagnosed with [insert other relevant conditions, e.g., coronary artery disease, peripheral arterial disease].

**Current Condition:**
During their hospital stay, the patient was managed for [insert current condition or primary issue being addressed, e.g., acute myocardial infarction, lower extremity vascular disease]. Their condition has been progressing steadily, and they have experienced [insert relevant symptoms, e.g., chest pain, shortness of breath].

**Procedures/Treatments:**
The patient underwent several procedures/treatments, including:

* Angioplasty with stenting for coronary artery disease
* Endovascular intervention for lower extremity vascular disease
* Revascularization procedures for peripheral arterial disease

**Medications:**
The patient was started on the following medications during their hospital stay:

* Antiplatelet agents (e.g., aspirin, clopidogrel)
* Anticoagulants (e.g., warfarin, heparin)
* Statins
* Beta-blockers

**Lab Results and Diagnostic Findings:**
The patient's lab results and diagnostic findings revealed the presence of [insert relevant lab abnormalities or diagnoses, e.g., elevated troponin levels, decreased ankle-brachial index]. These findings supported their current condition and informed their treatment plan.

**Progression and Disposition:**
The patient's condition has stabilized somewhat during their hospital stay. They are now in a more stable clinical state and can be safely discharged home with close follow-up care. The patient will require [insert any necessary follow-up appointments or medications] to manage their current condition effectively.

**Discharge Instructions:**
Please ensure the patient follows their medication regimen as prescribed, maintains a healthy diet, and engages in regular exercise to manage their conditions. They should also schedule follow-up appointments with their primary care physician to monitor their progress and adjust their treatment plan as needed.

This summary provides a general overview of the patient's medical history, current condition, and any relevant procedures or treatments received during their hospital stay. Please note that specific ICD-10 codes used in this report have been omitted for confidentiality and clarity purposes.

column1:
**Clinical Discharge Summary**

Patient Name: [Redact for confidentiality]

Date of Birth: [Redact for confidentiality]

Reason for Hospitalization: [Briefly describe the reason for hospitalization, e.g., "acute illness" or "medical procedure"]

Summary of Diagnosis:

The patient was hospitalized for evaluation and treatment of several medical conditions. The primary diagnoses include:

1. Gastrointestinal issues due to viral gastroenteritis, resulting in diarrhea and abdominal cramps.
2. Acute respiratory infection with symptoms of bronchitis, characterized by cough and shortness of breath.
3. Mental health concern related to anxiety disorder (F41.9), requiring ongoing support and management.
4. Chronic skin condition, eczema, with lesions on the elbows and knees.

Procedure:

The patient underwent a lumbar puncture (spinal tap) as part of their diagnostic evaluation for suspected meningitis-like symptoms.

Treatment Plan:

During hospitalization, the patient received:

* Antibiotics to treat bacterial infections
* Antiviral medication to manage viral gastroenteritis
* Bronchodilators and corticosteroids to alleviate respiratory symptoms
* Topical creams and oral medications to manage eczema symptoms
* Ongoing mental health support and counseling

Prognosis:

The patient is expected to make a full recovery with continued follow-up care. The treatment plan will focus on managing symptoms, preventing complications, and promoting overall well-being.

Discharge Instructions:

Upon discharge, the patient is advised to:

* Continue taking prescribed medications as directed
* Follow up with their primary care physician for ongoing management of chronic conditions
* Practice good hygiene to prevent the spread of infection (e.g., frequent handwashing)
* Seek mental health support through counseling or therapy if needed

Please note that this discharge summary does not include specific medical procedures or codes, but rather provides a general overview of the patient's diagnosis and treatment plan.

column1:
Clinical Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted for Privacy]

Date of Discharge: [Date]

Reason for Admission: The patient was admitted to the hospital with a complex medical condition involving multiple organ systems. Initial evaluation revealed signs and symptoms suggestive of [condition 1], which has progressed to [condition 2].

During their stay, the patient underwent several diagnostic procedures, including imaging studies and blood work, to better understand their overall health status. These tests revealed evidence of [condition 3] and [condition 4].

Medically, the patient was managed with a combination of medications aimed at controlling symptoms related to [condition 5]. Additionally, due to concomitant [condition 6], we implemented strategies to mitigate potential complications.

A significant aspect of the patient's care involved management of their cardiovascular system. Specifically, there were concerns regarding [cardiovascular condition]. The patient received close monitoring and treatment to ensure stability and prevent adverse outcomes.

The patient also presented with symptoms indicative of [neurological condition]. The clinical team provided supportive care, including medications designed to alleviate symptoms and improve quality of life.

Beyond the physical aspects of their health, the patient has been experiencing emotional challenges related to [mental health condition]. We have implemented a plan to address these concerns through ongoing therapy sessions.

Following several rounds of treatment and interventions, it became clear that the patient's most pressing need was related to their gastrointestinal well-being. This led to adjustments in their diet and medication regimen aimed at reducing symptoms associated with this issue.

Throughout their hospital stay, close monitoring and adjustments have been made to optimize the patient’s care plan. These efforts have resulted in a significant improvement in their overall condition, reducing the risk of complications and enabling them to prepare for discharge.

Discharge Instructions:

- Continue taking all prescribed medications as directed.
- Maintain a healthy diet, with particular emphasis on eating smaller, more frequent meals if experiencing symptoms related to [condition].
- Monitor vital signs closely, reporting any changes to your healthcare provider promptly.
- Schedule follow-up appointments as instructed by your healthcare team for ongoing management of [all conditions].

Precautions and Warnings:

- Patients should be advised about the potential risks associated with certain medications or activities during their recovery phase. This information will be provided in written form at discharge.

Discharge Summary Conclusion:
The patient’s care has been comprehensive, addressing multiple aspects of their health to ensure optimal well-being upon discharge. With close monitoring and adherence to prescribed treatments, we are confident that the patient will experience continued improvement over time.

Signed,

[Your Name]
Attending Physician

Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Omnipaque / oxaliplatin / Iodinated Contrast Media
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
fevers
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: 14 ___ Right Chest Tube Insertion 
___: Uncomplicated 18-gauge targeted liver biopsy x 3, with 
specimens sent to pathology and microbiology.
 
History of Present Illness:
================================================================ 


Oncology Hospitalist Admission

Date: ___

================================================================

PCP: ___
PRIMARY ONCOLOGIST: ___., MD
PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS: Pancreatic Cancer
TREATMENT REGIMEN: FOLFOX with Oxaliplatin Desensitization

CHIEF COMPLAINT: Fever

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:

Mr. ___ is a pleasant ___ years old Male who presents to
___ ED for the further evaluation of fever at home (tmax of
101). He has a complicated oncological history after undergoing
multiple chemo regimens and multiple Whipple attempts with prior
hepatic abscess drained by ___ and history of cholangitis that 
was
treated. He has required multiple GI interventions via MRCP for
micro abscesses on the liver and he has been on prophylactic
Augmentin for the past three weeks. Temperatures at home have
been slowly climbing up, 99.4 last night but reached 101 this 
AM.
His wife called her oncologist who recommended he come in for
further medical care. Pt also endorse back pain secondary to an
L5 bulging disc, for which he recently underwent a plexus block
on ___. He otherwise feels well and reports no other
constitutional symptoms. He denies any chills, chest pain,
shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain,
recent prolonged traveling, or known exposure to sick contacts.
Of note, last session of chemo was in ___ of this year.

In the ED, initial vitals: 101.5 92 128/74 16 94% RA
 
Past Medical History:
PAST ONCOLOGIC HISTORY: 

Pancreatic cancer stage IIA (T3N0M0)
- ___ Developed loose stool. 
- ___ Developed weight loss following TKR surgery despite
eating regularly. He reported increased frequency of his stools
for which he avoided lactose. 
- ___ He was seen by Dr. ___ who felt he had a
malabsorption from CF gene and f/u for this was started,
including an abdominal U/S to look at the pancreas. This
unfortunately revealed a 3.2 x 3.1 x 2.8 cm pancreatic head 
mass with PD dilatation worrisome for malignancy. Two
indeterminate hepatic masses were seen. 
- ___ He underwent EUS which revealed an ill-defined
pancreatic head mass w/o vascular involvement, which confirmed
moderately-differentiated pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma. CA
___ found to be elevated to 492. 
- ___ CTA torso showed an ill-defined, infiltrative
hypoattenuating mass in the head of the pancreas, consistent 
with
adenocarcinoma, resulting in pancreaticobiliary ductal
obstruction, and with stranding extending to superior 
mesenteric and splenic veins. Hyperenhancing lesion in the dome
of the liver may represent hemangioma, however is incompletely
characterized on this split bolus examination. 
- ___ Underwent attempted Whipple resection.
Intra-operatively, he was found to have a large, inflammatory
carcinoma measuring 7-8 cm occupying the entire pancreas into 
the
uncinate and down to the root of the mesentery (and 
down by the superior mesenteric vessels). Due to the severity of
the inflammatory pancreatitis and the size of the tumor were
prohibitive to proceed with an attempt at safe
pancreaticoduodenectomy resection. As such, it was 
determined to be locally invasive and open CCY and double bypass
performed, fiducials placed. Of note, the liver was also
inspected intra-operatively and the possible hemangioma seen in
the dome on imaging was not seen or palpable and the liver 
looked
healthy overall. Uncomplicated post-op course. 
- ___ C1D1 FOLFIRINOX
- ___ C1D1 DF/HCC ___ CAT-IQ trial
- ___ C2D1 FOLFIRINOX + Neulasta
- ___ CTA torso showed stable disease, new line 
associated
clot. Holding isoquercetin and switch to enoxaparin. 
Chemotherapy
hold for toxicity
- ___ C3D1 FOLFOX6 (holding IRI from FOLFIRINOX)
- ___ - ___ Admitted with fever, found to have Ecoli
bacteremia. 
- ___ C3D15 FOLFIRNOX (IRI reduced by 50% to 90 mg/m2)
- ___ SBRT to tumor
- ___ held FOLFIRINOX given stomach pain, fatigue, LFTs up
- ___ FOLFOX, found to have UGT1A1 polymorphism
- ___ CTA torso showed decrease in the pancreatic mass 
and
no metastatic disease. Felt to represent resectable disease
- ___ Taken to the OR for curative attempt with a 
Whipple.
Liver lesions noted during the procedure. Biopsies were taken 
and
fresh sections read as adenocarcinoma, so Whipple was aborted.
Final pathology showed biliary hamartomas however. 
- ___ MR abdomen showed 2.9 x 2.7 cm pancreatic head mass
contacting the SMV less than 90 degrees with associated distal
pancreas atrophy. No definite metastases in the abdomen,
including liver.
- ___ Third attempt at Whipple found inoperable vascular
involvement at the SMV root
- ___ CT torso showed stable locally advanced disease, no
metastatic disease
- ___ CTA showed continued gradual decrease in size of
pancreatic mass, no metastatic disease
- ___ CT torso showed stable disease, no metastatic
disease
- ___ CT torso showed stable disease, no metastatic
disease
- ___ CT torso showed stable disease, no metastatic
disease
- ___ CT torso showed stable disease, no metastatic
disease
- ___ CT torso showed stable disease, no metastatic
disease
- ___ CT torso showed stable disease, no metastatic
disease
- ___ EUS with path showing adenocarcinoma, ERCP unable 
to
be performed due to anatomy
- ___ CT torso showed stable disease, no metastatic
disease, small, nonocclusive thrombus of the portal vein.
- ___ CT torso showed stable disease
- ___ CT chest showed 7 tiny (<5mm) lung nodules
- ___ PET with 3.5 x 2.5 cm pancreatic head mass; No 
other
areas of abnormal FDG uptake noted.
- ___ - ___ Admitted for slowed speech, found to have
epileptiform discharges and started on keppra. brain MRI neg 
- ___ CT chest ___. MR abdomen progressive disease of
pancreatic head
- ___ FOLFOX C1D1
- ___ FOLFOX C1D15 held due to oxaliplatin reaction
- ___ MRCP with slightly improved cholangitis, stable
disease
- ___ FOLFOX C2D1 with inpatient oxaliplatin
desensitization
- ___ FOLFOX C2D15 with inpatient oxaliplatin
desensitization
- ___: admitted with fevers, found to have liver
abscesses
- ___: MRI with improved cholangitis, stable panc head mass
- ___: FOLFOX C3D1 with inpatient oxaliplatin
desensitization
- ___: FOLFOX C3D15 with inpatient oxaliplatin
desensitizaton
- ___: EGD with banding of two grade II-III varices
- ___ CT chest and MR abdomen showed persistent evidence
of cholangitis but resolved abscess, stable disease
- ___ C4D1 mFOLFOX with oxali densensitization (LV 200
mg/m2 ci5FU 960 mg/m2/day) + Neulasta
- ___ CT chest and MR abdomen show stable chronic
cholangitis and stable disease
- ___ MRCP with stable chronic cholangitis, stable
pancreatic head mass, and subcentimeter lesions in segment 4A 
and
8 consistent with either microabscesses or metastatic lesions

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  

- Pancreatic Cancer, as above
- Portal Vein Thrombus
- Opioid Use Disorder on Suboxone
- s/p total knee replacement
- s/p appendectomy
- L5 Disc herniation

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
 1.  Mother died of cholangiocarcinoma.
 2.  Father was unknown to him, but died in his ___.
 3.  No other family history of malignancy.

 
Physical Exam:
VITAL SIGNS: ___ ___ Temp: 98.0 PO BP: 130/78 HR: 85 RR: 
16 O2 sat: 97% O2 delivery: RA 
General:  NAD
HEENT:  MMM

base

baseline
LIMBS:  No ___, WWP
SKIN:  No rashes on extremities
NEURO:  Speech fluent, strength grossly intact
PSYCH: thought process logical, linear, future oriented
ACCESS: chest port site intact w/o erythema, dressing C/D/I
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 05:02AM BLOOD WBC-13.7* RBC-3.60* Hgb-8.6* Hct-27.3* 
MCV-76* MCH-23.9* MCHC-31.5* RDW-19.5* RDWSD-53.5* Plt ___
___ 05:55AM BLOOD Glucose-178* UreaN-10 Creat-0.5 Na-135 
K-4.3 Cl-99 HCO3-22 AnGap-14

___ 05:02AM BLOOD Iron-14*
___ 05:55AM BLOOD Calcium-8.2* Phos-2.4* Mg-1.9
___ 05:02AM BLOOD calTIBC-198* Ferritn-147 TRF-152*
___ 01:14PM BLOOD CEA-84.0*
___ 01:14PM BLOOD CA ___ -PND
___ 10:15AM PLEURAL TNC-2200* ___ Polys-55* 
Lymphs-5* Monos-1* Baso-1* Macro-38* Other-0
___ 10:15AM PLEURAL TotProt-4.0 Glucose-104 LD(LDH)-368 
Albumin-2.1 Cholest-62 proBNP-___ w/ locally advanced, non-resectable pancreatic cancer s/p
chemo and SBRT, on FOLFOX w/ desens, whose course has been c/b
recurrent bouts of cholangitis and hepatic abscess, p/w sepsis 
on
___ after having a plexus block on ___.

# Sepsis, resolving

Patient presented with fever, tachycardia, leukocytosis, despite
taking augmentin. Suspect most likely source is biliary with
elevated lfts and absence of any localizing symptoms. He quickly
improved with IV Zosyn. Imaging (MRCP, CT-torso) c/w metastatic 
disease rather
than cholangitis or abscesses. ID consulted and advised holding
abx, but ok to resume home prophylactic abx. Imaging and case
reviewed at tumor board today and noted that his findings are 
not
entirely clear w/ progression and recommended biopsy. 
He had a targeted liver biopsy ___ and the preliminary path
is not c/w abscess, more suggestive of malignancy. This was
relayed to the oncology team and they will follow up the 
results. 

- cont po cipro for prophylaxis
- oncology will arrange a f/u 

# Pleural Effusion
Has symptomatic new effusion w/ septations. S/p CP placement on
___ with over 1000 ml serosangeonous fluid removed and
symptomatic improvement. Studies c/w simple exudative effusion.
- IP will arrange a f/u

# Pancreatic Ca
He is undergoing palliative FOLFOX w/ oxali desens. Disease has
been under control but imaging c/f progression. 
- liver abscess-vs-met pathology/micro report pending
- cont creon

# PVT: cont apixaban 

# History of idiopathic seizure (word finding difficulties,
slowed speech, hand or finger jumping)
He states he has not had any further episodes of seizures since
the admission for it ___. He is now off zonisamide 

# History of opiate abuse: cont suboxone
# Anemia: likely from antineoplastic therapy 
# L5 Disc herniation: cont flexeril prn, has outpatient f/u

FEN: Regular
ACCESS: PORT
CODE STATUS: Full code, presumed  
DISPO: Onc-hosp, home w/o services
BILLING: >30 min spent coordinating care for discharge
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Amoxicillin-Clavulanic Acid ___ mg PO Q12H 
2. Cyclobenzaprine 10 mg PO TID:PRN back pain 
3. Creon 12 1 CAP PO TID W/MEALS 
4. Apixaban 5 mg PO BID

7. Vitamin D 1000 UNIT PO DAILY

RX *ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*28 Tablet Refills:*0 
2.  Apixaban 5 mg PO BID 
DO NOT RESUME UNTIL ___ IN AFTERNOON  
3.  Buprenorphine 1.4 mg SL DAILY

5.  Cyclobenzaprine 10 mg PO TID:PRN back pain  
6.  Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H  
7.  Vitamin D 1000 UNIT PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Sepsis
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
 
Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure caring for you in the hospital. You were 
admitted for fever workup and found to have imaging findings 
concerning for possible metastatic disease that is progressing 
but discussions at tumor board feels these are more likely 
abscess. To help investigate this further, you had a liver 
biopsy done on ___. You can resume your apixaban 24 hours after 
your liver biopsy on ___. Your oncology team will follow up on 
the results. If you have any abdominal pain, especially in your 
right upper abdomen, or any dizziness and lightheadedness, this 
could be a sign of internal bleeding in the liver and you will 
need to seek immediate medical attention.

You also had a pleural effusion and you had the fluid drained 
from your lung with a chest tube. Interventional Pulmonology 
will call you with a follow up appointment. 

Wishing you best health,
Dr. ___ your ___ team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE

lovastatin / NSAIDS (Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drug)
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Hematemesis
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
EGD - ___
 
History of Present Illness:
Patient is a ___ w/ obesity s/p Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, known 
large gastrojejunal ulcer, severe PVD s/p multiple vascular 
interventions (most recently s/p BKA on ___, and chronic 
back/extremity pain on methadone who presents to the ED with 
hematemesis. 

Of note, the patient was discharged from ___ after a 
hospitalization ___ during which she underwent L BKA for 
severe wound infection.  She then went to her rehab facility & 
had ___ episodes of hematemesis prompting return to ___.  

On admission, she denied any BRBPR, melena, chest pain, 
lightheadedness, dizziness, abdominal pain, fevers or chills.

In the ED, she had continued hematemesis so was intubated 
emergently for airway protection.  She was sedated w/ fentanyl   
Her initial vital signs were T 98.1, HR 97, BP 121/68, RR18 O2 
98%.  Her HGB was 6.6 from 8.2 so she was transfused 2U pRBCs. 
GI, ACS & Vascular Surgery were consulted for management. 

On arrival to the ICU, the patient remained intubated & sedated. 
 She was HDS.  
 
Past Medical History:
Nephrolithiasis  
 Recurrent lower extremity cellulitis  
 Hypertension  
 Hyperlipidemia  
 Type 2 diabetes  
 Peripheral vascular disease with bilateral foot ulceration and

BRIEF HOSPITAL COURSE:
======================
Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old male with HLD and T2DM who presented 
with one day of RUQ pain, direct hyperbilirubinemia, fevers, 
rigors, and imaging consistent with acute cholangitis and found 
to have Ecoli bacteremia. Pt was fluid resuscitated and started 
on zosyn. S/p ERCP with sphincterotomy with visualized pus, 
stones, and sludge and stent placement. Plan for laparoscopic 
cholecystectomy this admission. 

# Sepsis with Ecoli bacteremia 
# Cholangitis: 
# Acute cholecystitis:
Patient presented with epigastric, RUQ pain with elevated Dbili, 
elevated ALT/AST, and febrile in the ED to 103.2, though initial 
WBC was normal. RUQ with evidence of sludge and gallbladder 
edema consistent with acute cholecystitis and mild dilation of 
intra and extrahepatic ducts (up to 14mm) concerning for 
cholangitis. Was mildly hypotensive in the ED and received 3.5L 
of IVF and started on zosyn (Day 1: ___. ERCP on ___ with 
sphincterotomy showed pus, stones, and sludge. Stent was placed. 
Blood cultures grew pan-sensitive Ecoli and antibiotics were 
narrowed to linezolid and ciprofloxacin for 14 day course total 
post op (including IV antibiotics given in patient). ACS 
conducted lap cholecystectomy on ___. Patient will follow 
up with ERCP for stent removal in 4 weeks. 

# ___: 
Presented with Cr elevated to 1.3. Unknown baseline, but patient 
does not report any known kidney disease. Following fluid 
resuscitation, Cr decreased to 1.0, likely at baseline. 

# Coagulopathy: 
Patient presented with INR of 1.3 which uptrended to 1.4. Likely 
from decreased PO intake but given steatosis on RUQUS, cannot 
rule out cirrhosis. History of drinking in the past. Would 
follow up dedicated cirrhosis evaluation as outpatient. INR 
downtrended to 1.1. 

# Mild Anemia: 
Hgb downtrended from 13.3 to 10.9 iso receiving IVF. No signs of 
active bleeding.

# HLD:

Surgical Course:

The patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy on ___, 
which went well without complication (Please see operative 
report for details). After a brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, 
the patient arrived on the floor tolerating clear liquid diet, 
on IV fluids, and IV medication for pain control. The patient 
was hemodynamically stable.

Pain was well controlled. Diet was progressively advanced as 
tolerated to a regular diet with good tolerability. The patient 
voided without problem. During this hospitalization, the patient 
ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with respiratory 
toilet and incentive spirometry, and actively participated in 
the plan of care. The patient received subcutaneous heparin and 
venodyne boots were used during this stay.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled. The patient was discharged home without services. 
The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up 
instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with 
the discharge plan.

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Sepsis
Cholangitis 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain. You 
developed a low blood pressure despite intravenous fluids and 
because of this, you were transferred to the intensive care unit 
for management. You were also reported to have elevated liver 
enzymes. You underwent imaging and found to have cholecystitis 
and you were started on a course of zosyn. You underwent an ERCP 
where a sphincterotomy was done with removal of sludge, stones 
and pus. Plastic stents were placed in the CBD and PD. You will 
have a follow up appointment with endoscopy to remove the 
stents. You were then taken to the operating room where you had 
removal of the gallbladder. During your hospitalization, you 
were found to have bacteria in your blood. The infectious 
disease service was consulted and you were started on a course 
of antibiotics.

Please have your blood work done at the ___ floor lab prior to 
your scheduled follow up appointment.

You have done well since surgery and are preparing for discharge 
home with the following instructions:      
 
ACTIVITY:
 
o Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
o You may climb stairs. 
o  You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until 
you see your surgeon at your next visit.
o  Don't lift more than ___ lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about 
the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies 
to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
o You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
o You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
 
HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
o  You may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. You 
might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
o  You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
o  You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. 
You might feel somewhat depressed.
o  You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
unappealing.
o  All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
o Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your 
incisions. Under these dressing you have small plastic bandages 
called steri-strips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. 
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your 
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay).
o Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This 
is normal.
o You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
o Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
o Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
o You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid 
staining your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, 
please call your surgeon.
o You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
o Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medications. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
o If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain 
moving the bowels, call your surgeon. 
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
o Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain 
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
o You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do 
not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed.
o Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
o Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
o If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
o Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you 
cough or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Confused - sometimes.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Activity
 We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
 You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 
___ try to do too much all at once.
 No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
 If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
allowed to drive by law. 
 No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You 
should avoid contact sports for 6 months. 

Medications
 Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
 You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You ___ Experience:
 You may have difficulty paying attention, concentrating, and 
remembering new information.
 Emotional and/or behavioral difficulties are common. 
 Feeling more tired, restlessness, irritability, and mood 
swings are also common.
 Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

Headaches:
 Headache is one of the most common symptom after a brain 
bleed. 
 Most headaches are not dangerous but you should call your 
doctor if the headache gets worse, develop arm or leg weakness, 
increased sleepiness, and/or have nausea or vomiting with a 
headache. 
 Mild pain medications may be helpful with these headaches but 
avoid taking pain medications on a daily basis unless prescribed 
by your doctor. 
 There are other things that can be done to help with your 
headaches: avoid caffeine, get enough sleep, daily exercise, 
relaxation/ meditation, massage, acupuncture, heat or ice packs. 


When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
 Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
 Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
 Nausea and/or vomiting
 Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
 Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers
 Seizures
 Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
 Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg
 
Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience 
any of the following:
 Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg
 Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding
 Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
coordination
 Sudden severe headaches with no known reason

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted because of difficulty breathing. We gave you 
oxygen and performed imaging of your lungs. We found that you 
had an infection of your lungs (pneumonia) that worsened your 
COPD, as well as a collection of fluid in your lungs which was 
drained with a chest tube. We treated you with antibiotics, 
steroids, and nebulizers to help treat the infection and the 
COPD flair. Please complete your remaining 3 days of doxycycline 
antibiotics at home as instructed.  During your stay you were 
also informed of your diagnosis of lung cancer from a previous 
lung biopsy. Please follow up with the cancer team (oncology) on 
___ for further care.

Your blood sugar was elevated prior to discharge. Please monitor 
your blood sugars more frequently for the next couple of days 
and contact your PCP if your BG <80 or BG >200.

Upon discharge, please weigh yourself every morning, call MD if 
weight goes up more than 3 lbs. Monitor yourself for fevers, 
chills, difficulty breathing, nausea, vomiting, or any other 
concerning symptoms that may be an indicator that the infection 
is worsening. Continue to use 2 Liters of oxygen during the day, 
in addition to your original amount of 2 liters of oxygen at 
night.

Please note that your warfarin dose was changed in the hospital 
to 4mg every day by mouth. Please follow up with your primary 
care physician on ___, ___ at 9am to have your INR 
checked, along with your potassium (which was low during your 
hospitalization), and have the stitch where the chest tube was 
placed removed.

Your home dose of carvedilol for your blood pressure was also 
cut in half per cardiology. Please set up care with a 
cardiologist once you leave the hospital (you will be receiving 
a call from the hospital to arrange this) to discuss the doses 
for you heart medications.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with hx CREST syndrome, HTN, vasculitis, neuropathy, DVT, 
Factor V leiden, on coumadin, originally presented to OSH 
following an episode of syncope with complicated hospital 
course, transferred to ___ on ___ for management of 
severe pulmonary hypertension. Hospital course notable for ICU 
transfer following PEA arrest, volume directed management of 
pulmonary hypertension with pulmonary, and persistent hypoxemia. 
Patient was transferred to floor after weaned down on O2 and off 
of pressors. She continued diuresis on the floor and continued 
to improve. She was discharged to rehab. 

ACUTE ISSUES:  
=============
# PEA Arrest. On the morning o ___, patient collapsed in bed. 
CODE BLUE called for PEA arrest. ROSC was obtained after ___ min 
of CPR and 1 round of epi. Etiology of cardiac arrest was 
thought likely secondary to worsening pulmonary hypertension and 
flash pulmonary edema. She was transferred to the unit for 
pressure support and aggressive diuresis. She was significantly 
improved on discharge.   

# Pulmonary HTN. After PEA arrest, repeat TTE demonstrated 
increased dilation of RV cavity with severe global free wall 
hypokinesis progressed from prior TTE. Pulmonary consult was 
obtained. She was started on epoprostenol, which was then 
weaned. She had PA catheter placed for directed therapy. She was 
started on Sidenafil, increased to 20mg TID. She did well with 
diuresis and was discharged on 20mg Sildenafil and daily PO 
Lasix.   

# Hypoxemia. Following PEA arrest, patient was persistently 
hypoxic requiring high flow nasal canuala. CTA was negative for 
PE but was concerning for flash pulm edema vs ?pulm hemorrhage. 
There was consideration of steroids to treat empiric for 
possible inflammatory process, but this was deferred given prior 
scleroderma renal crisis and high risk of recurrence. She was 
managed with BIPAP then transitioned to high flow nasal canula, 
which was eventually able to be weaned to nasal canula and 
transferred to the floor. Her respiratory status continued to 
improve with aggressive diuresis prior to discharge.  She had 
decreased ___ of NC on discharge. She will continue to need 
diuresis as tolerated and continued weaning of O2. 

# Shock: hypotensive post arrest initially requiring epinephrine 
drip. Epinephrine was changed to levophed and dobutamine after 
she developed cool lower extremities and there was concern for 
developing cyanosis. Hypotension likely cardiogenic due to right 
sided failure given no evidence of infection. Dobutamine was 
stopped but she intermittently required levophed throughout her 
ICU stay. With optimization of her pulmonary hypertension and 
volume status, she was weaned off of pressors and transferred to 
the floor. She did well from a BP stand point. She was 
hypotensive on ___ due to aggressive diuresis which improved 
with 500cc of oral water intake. BP had dropped to ___ and 
improved to 100s systolics. 

# ___: creatinine 2.9 on admission, down from 5s at OSH after 
blood and fluid resuscitation. She was then thought to be 
acutely volume overloaded. She was diuresed and creatnine had 
improved to 1.1 by time of discharge.

# Factor V Leiden-Heterogenous: Patient has a hx of DVT. CTA was 
obtained post arrest and was negative for PE. Repeat LENIs 
negative. Anticoagulation was initially held for question of a 
possible hemorrhage, however she remained stable and was 
re-started on anticoagulation with apixaban 5mg BID.    
  
# CREST syndrome: followed by rheumatology here. Seen by 
rheumatology, who recommended avoiding all steroids given high 
risk of recurrent scleroderma renal crisis. Patient reported 
that she has not taken steroids for more than ___ years. 
  
# Anemia: s/p 2 units PRBCs at OSH, per d/c summary HCt has 
remained stable. Multiple stool guaiacs have been positive. Iron 
studies consistent with anemia of chronic disease. The patient 
required 1u PRBCs during her stay and she responded 
appropriately. Her hemoglobin otherwise remained stable 
throughout hospital course. She will need outpatient follow up 
for her anemia. 

# UTI: pan-sensitive E.coli growing at OSH s/p 3 day course of 
CTX (___).  

# C-DIFF Diarrhea: Patient developed c-diff positive diarrhea. 
She was started on Vancomycin PO on ___. The vancomycin course 
was prolonged after a concern for a UTI on ___ with two days of 
ceftriaxone. Her diarrhea has improved. She will continue the PO 
vancomycin until ___.

the
duodenal limb. He was also noted to have a small nodular opacity 
within the common and right bile duct potentially representing 
sludge or debris. Over his hospitalization, his Na increased 
from 125 to 132. He was also noted to be confused and was 
treated for hepatic encephalopathy. 

In terms of his pancreatic cancer, it was diagnosed in ___ 
after a CT scan performed for evaluation of localized prostate

moderately
differentiated, grade 2. He was started on adjuvant gemcitabine,

developed a pulmonary embolism during his hospitalization that

In ___, he had imaging that revealed a potential liver lesion 
and ascites. He was ultimately diagnosed with cirrhosis, likely

#Right parietal brain lesion

to the OR and underwent a right craniotomy for resection of

He underwent a post-operative head CT which showed expected 
post-operative changes. He was later transferred to the ___ for 
close neurologic monitoring. On ___, the patient remained 
neurologically stable on examination. He underwent post-op MRI 
which showed expected post-operative changes. He was transferred 
to the floor. His neurological exam remained stable as he 
awaited disposition planning. 

#Intraparenchymal hemorrhage/Subdural hematoma
In the evening of ___, the patient fell and struck his head. 
His neurological exam was significantly worse and he was sent 
for a STAT NCHCT, which showed intraparenchymal hemorrhage and 
acute subdural hematoma with mass effect and significant midline 
shift. He was taken emergently to the operating room for right 
craniotomy for evacuation of clot. The procedure was 
uncomplicated. For further procedure details, please see 
separately dictated operative report by Dr. ___. 
Post-operative NCHCT showed good evacuation of the clot with 
improved midline shift. He was transferred to the NICU for close 
neurological monitoring. He remained in the Neuro ICU on ___ 
for close neurologic monitoring. On ___, he was transferred to 
the ___. On ___, he was transferred to the floor. Case 
management screened for rehab placement. 

#Hyponatremia
The patient was started on salt tablets three times daily 
post-operatively. His serum Na continued to be checked daily. On 
___, the patient underwent placement of a PICC line for 
continued 3% HTS. This was weaned as tolerated. On ___, he was 
started on salt tabs. 3% HTS was discontinued ___. He was able 
to maintain appropriate serum sodium levels. On ___, PICC line 
was removed. He remained on salt tabs 2gm TID with a stable 
sodium level of 138.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions
Brain Tumor

Surgery
You underwent surgery to remove a brain lesion from your brain 
and you returned to the OR to evacuate a hemorrhage that 
developed post-operatively. 
Please keep your incision dry until your sutures/staples are 
removed. 
You may shower at this time but keep your incision dry.
It is best to keep your incision open to air but it is ok to 
cover it when outside. 
Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 
___ try to do too much all at once.
No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
allowed to drive by law. 
No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You 
should avoid contact sports for 6 months. 

Medications
Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
You have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam). This 
medication helps to prevent seizures. Please continue this 
medication as indicated on your discharge instruction. It is 
important that you take this medication consistently and on 
time. 
You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You ___ Experience:
You may experience headaches and incisional pain. 
You may also experience some post-operative swelling around 
your face and eyes. This is normal after surgery and most 
noticeable on the second and third day of surgery.  You apply 
ice or a cool or warm washcloth to your eyes to help with the 
swelling. The swelling will be its worse in the morning after 
laying flat from sleeping but decrease when up. 
You may experience soreness with chewing. This is normal from 
the surgery and will improve with time. Softer foods may be 
easier during this time. 
Feeling more tired or restlessness is also common.
Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
Nausea and/or vomiting
Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers
Seizures
Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience 
any of the following:
Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg
Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding
Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
coordination
Sudden severe headaches with no known reason

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with hx CREST syndrome, HTN, vasculitis, neuropathy, DVT, 
Factor V leiden, on coumadin, originally presented to OSH 
following an episode of syncope with complicated hospital 
course, transferred to ___ on ___ for management of 
severe pulmonary hypertension. Hospital course notable for ICU 
transfer following PEA arrest, volume directed management of 
pulmonary hypertension with pulmonary, and persistent hypoxemia. 
Patient was transferred to floor after weaned down on O2 and off 
of pressors. She continued diuresis on the floor and continued 
to improve. She was discharged to rehab. 

ACUTE ISSUES:  
=============
# PEA Arrest. On the morning o ___, patient collapsed in bed. 
CODE BLUE called for PEA arrest. ROSC was obtained after ___ min 
of CPR and 1 round of epi. Etiology of cardiac arrest was 
thought likely secondary to worsening pulmonary hypertension and 
flash pulmonary edema. She was transferred to the unit for 
pressure support and aggressive diuresis. She was significantly 
improved on discharge.   

# Pulmonary HTN. After PEA arrest, repeat TTE demonstrated 
increased dilation of RV cavity with severe global free wall 
hypokinesis progressed from prior TTE. Pulmonary consult was 
obtained. She was started on epoprostenol, which was then 
weaned. She had PA catheter placed for directed therapy. She was 
started on Sidenafil, increased to 20mg TID. She did well with 
diuresis and was discharged on 20mg Sildenafil and daily PO 
Lasix.   

# Hypoxemia. Following PEA arrest, patient was persistently 
hypoxic requiring high flow nasal canuala. CTA was negative for 
PE but was concerning for flash pulm edema vs ?pulm hemorrhage. 
There was consideration of steroids to treat empiric for 
possible inflammatory process, but this was deferred given prior 
scleroderma renal crisis and high risk of recurrence. She was 
managed with BIPAP then transitioned to high flow nasal canula, 
which was eventually able to be weaned to nasal canula and 
transferred to the floor. Her respiratory status continued to 
improve with aggressive diuresis prior to discharge.  She had 
decreased ___ of NC on discharge. She will continue to need 
diuresis as tolerated and continued weaning of O2. 

# Shock: hypotensive post arrest initially requiring epinephrine 
drip. Epinephrine was changed to levophed and dobutamine after 
she developed cool lower extremities and there was concern for 
developing cyanosis. Hypotension likely cardiogenic due to right 
sided failure given no evidence of infection. Dobutamine was 
stopped but she intermittently required levophed throughout her 
ICU stay. With optimization of her pulmonary hypertension and 
volume status, she was weaned off of pressors and transferred to 
the floor. She did well from a BP stand point. She was 
hypotensive on ___ due to aggressive diuresis which improved 
with 500cc of oral water intake. BP had dropped to ___ and 
improved to 100s systolics. 

# ___: creatinine 2.9 on admission, down from 5s at OSH after 
blood and fluid resuscitation. She was then thought to be 
acutely volume overloaded. She was diuresed and creatnine had 
improved to 1.1 by time of discharge.

# Factor V Leiden-Heterogenous: Patient has a hx of DVT. CTA was 
obtained post arrest and was negative for PE. Repeat LENIs 
negative. Anticoagulation was initially held for question of a 
possible hemorrhage, however she remained stable and was 
re-started on anticoagulation with apixaban 5mg BID.    
  
# CREST syndrome: followed by rheumatology here. Seen by 
rheumatology, who recommended avoiding all steroids given high 
risk of recurrent scleroderma renal crisis. Patient reported 
that she has not taken steroids for more than ___ years. 
  
# Anemia: s/p 2 units PRBCs at OSH, per d/c summary HCt has 
remained stable. Multiple stool guaiacs have been positive. Iron 
studies consistent with anemia of chronic disease. The patient 
required 1u PRBCs during her stay and she responded 
appropriately. Her hemoglobin otherwise remained stable 
throughout hospital course. She will need outpatient follow up 
for her anemia. 

# UTI: pan-sensitive E.coli growing at OSH s/p 3 day course of 
CTX (___).  

# C-DIFF Diarrhea: Patient developed c-diff positive diarrhea. 
She was started on Vancomycin PO on ___. The vancomycin course 
was prolonged after a concern for a UTI on ___ with two days of 
ceftriaxone. Her diarrhea has improved. She will continue the PO 
vancomycin until ___.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the General Surgical Service on ___ 
for evaluation and treatment of abdominal pain.  Admission 
abdominal/pelvic CT revealed an inflamed and thickened appendix. 
  There was extensive stranding with small amount of fluid 
surrounding the whole length of the appendix. WBC was within 
normal limits. The patient underwent laparoscopic appendectomy,  
without complication (reader referred to the Operative Note for 
details). JP drain was placed during surgery. After a brief, 
uneventful stay in the PACU, the patient arrived on the floor 
with IV fluids infusing and IV dilaudid for pain relief. The 
patient was hemodynamically stable.

When tolerating a diet, the patient was converted to oral pain 
medication with continued good effect. Diet was progressively 
advanced as tolerated to a regular diet with good tolerability. 
The patient voided without problem. During this hospitalization, 
the patient ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with 
respiratory toilet and incentive spirometry, and actively 
participated in the plan of care. The patient received 
subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this 
stay. JP drain output was recorded and insertion site was 
monitored.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs.  The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient was discharged home without services. 
The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up 
instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with 
the discharge plan.

Dear ___,

___ were admitted to ___ because ___ were having abdominal 
pain. An abdomen/pelvis CT that was done showed acute 
appendicitis, which means your appendix was infected and there 
was a perforation. This resulted in your abdominal wall being 
inflamed/infected, also called peritonitis. ___ were brought to 
the OR emergently to have your appendix removed. After this 
procedure, ___ were monitored in the PACU before ___ were 
transferred to the floor. Your diet was slowly advanced until 
___ were tolerating a regular diet. ___ pain was controlled 
initially on IV pain medications, but was switched to oral pain 
medications once ___ were tolerating a PO intake. ___ were 
started on a course of antibiotics.

Please follow the discharge instructions below:
ACTIVITY:
 
o Do not drive until ___ have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel ___ could respond in an emergency.
o ___ may climb stairs. 
o  ___ may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until 
___ see your surgeon at your next visit.
o  Don't lift more than ___ lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about 
the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies 
to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
o ___ may start some light exercise when ___ feel comfortable.
o ___ will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when ___ 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
 
HOW ___ MAY FEEL: 
o  ___ may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. ___ 
might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust ___.
o  ___ may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
o  ___ might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. 
___ might feel somewhat depressed.
o  ___ could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
unappealing.
o  All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
o Tomorrow ___ may shower and remove the gauzes over your 
incisions. Under these dressing ___ have small plastic bandages 
called steri-strips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. 
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your 
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay).
o Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This 
is normal.
o ___ may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
o Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
o Do not use any ointments on the incision unless ___ were told 
otherwise.
o ___ may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid 
staining your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, 
please call your surgeon.
o ___ may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when ___ may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
o Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medications. If needed, ___ may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. ___ can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
o If ___ go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain 
moving the bowels, call your surgeon. 
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
o Your pain should get better day by day. If ___ find the pain 
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
o ___ will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do 
not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed.
o Your pain medicine will work better if ___ take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
o Talk with your surgeon about how long ___ will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
o If ___ are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
o Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when ___ 
cough or when ___ are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If ___ experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines ___ were on before the operation just as 
___ did before, unless ___ have been told differently.
If ___ have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Discharge Instructions:
Dear  ___

You were admitted for an autologous stem cell transplant. 

You had a fever and mouth pain while your blood counts were low. 
We did a work up including blood testing, urine testing, and 
chest x rays which did not find a source of infection. You were 
placed on antibiotics for your fever spikes and your fevers 
resolved. 

You also developed nausea, diarrhea and loss of appetite while 
you were admitted. These are common side effects after 
transplant and your symptoms continue to improve.
Your nausea medications are as follows:
1 compazine
2 ativan

You will continue to take acyclovir to prevent infection. You 
will start to take Bactrim to prevent a certain type of 
pneumonia once your counts have fully recovered. Your outpatient 
provider ___ tell you when to start this. 

Please take your temperature twice a day, and call us if it goes 
above 100.4.  Please be sure to drink at least 2L (64oz) of 
fluid daily. Call if you are unable to do so, or if you have 
worsening nausea or watery stools.

It has been a pleasure taking care of you.

Discharge Instructions:
Lumbar decompression with fusion:

You have undergone the following operation: Lumbar Decompression 
With Fusion

Immediately after the operation:

                Activity: You should not lift anything greater 
than 10 lbs for 2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do 
not sit or stand more than ~45 minutes without getting up and 
walking around.

                Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy:

___                ___ times a day you should go for a walk 
for ___ minutes as part of your recovery.  You can walk as 
much as you can tolerate.

___                Limit any kind of lifting.

                Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have 
some constipation after surgery.  You have been given medication 
to help with this issue.

                Brace: You may have been given a brace. This 
brace is to be worn when you are walking. You may take it off 
when sitting in a chair or while lying in bed.

                Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days.  If 
the incision is draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.  
If it is dry then you can leave the incision open to the air.  
Once the incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the 
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.  If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile 
dressing.  Call the office.

                You should resume taking your normal home 
medications.

                You have also been given Additional Medications 
to control your pain.  Please allow 72 hours for refill of 
narcotic prescriptions, so please plan ahead.  You can either 
have them mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic 
located on ___.  We are not allowed to call in or fax 
narcotic prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to your 
pharmacy.  In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain 
medications for 90 days from the date of surgery.

                Follow up:            

___                Please Call the office and make an 
appointment for 2 weeks after the day of your operation if this 
has not been done already.

___                At the 2-week visit we will check your 
incision, take baseline X-rays and answer any questions. We may 
at that time start physical therapy.

___                We will then see you at 6 weeks from the 
day of the operation and at that time release you to full 
activity.

Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo M with PMH NASH cirrhosis ___ year status post TIPS, whose 
cirrhosis is c/b banded varices, hepatic encephalopathy, hepatic 
hydrothorax), diverticulitis, GERD, who presented with GI 
bleeding, sepsis and empyema. 

Pt initially required MICU level of care for stability of his 
blood loss as well as newly-developing respiratory failure. His 
respiratory failure was found to be from a right-sided empyema 
requiring chest tube. The patient was started on Ceftrixone for 
antibiotics, eventually transitioned to a prolonged course of 
augmentin (final dose through ___.

The patient had evidence of ___ as well as sepsis while in 
the MICU; the ___ thought to be multifactorial from infection in 
the setting of liver disease. He required two sessions of HD. He 
was given albumin and midodrine, to some response. When his 
respiratory status and oxygenation were stable, he was 
called-out to the floor. 

While on the floor, underwent exchange of chest tube- pleurx 
catheter was placed. Pt was diuresed with iV diuretics. when he 
was more euvolemic, he was transitioned to PO furosemide for his 
diuretic regimen. His oxygen requirement resolved after 
achievement of euvolemia. On ___, Pt underwent a repeat CT 
scan to assess for stability of his effusions. This scan 
demonstrated interval improvement. Given the decreasing amounts 
of daily drainage that Pt had from his tube, as well as 
improvement of the empyema, the Interventional Pulmonary team 
pulled his chest tube. He was discharged with close follow-up 
with his hepatologist and the Interventional Pulmonary team. Abx 
were to be continued for 1 week following CT removal.

DETAILED HOSPITAL COURSE:

#Empyema
# Hypoxic respiratory failure: 
Initially requiring supplementary oxygen on arrival. Imaging 
demonstrated the presence of a right-sided pleural effusion, 
with pleural fluid studies concerning for spontaneous bacterial 
empyema vs. infected hepatic hydrothorax. Pt underwent chest 
tube placement with eventual exchange to PleurX catheter when 
the drainage decreased. His chest tube drainage appeared 
transiently bloody but had a hematocrit of < 10, so no further 
angiographic studies obtained. Initially covered with 
ceftriaxone, then transitioned to amoxicillin-clavulanic acid 
for a prolonged course (___). After downsizing to R TPC, 
Pt's PleurX had progressively decreasing fluid amounts with 
daily drainage. A CT scan on ___ demonstrated improvement of his 
hydrothorax, and per discussion with Interventional Pulmonary 
the tube was removed on ___. 
- After completion of his amox-clav (through ___, Pt should 
start ciprofloxacin 500mg q24h for SBP prophylaxis. 

# Acute-on-chronic anemia: 
Had one episode of hematemesis prior to arrival. No further 
evidence of this during hospitalization. No EGD performed. 
Without significant blood loss from his chest tube placement. 
Transiently downtrended and required a total of 4uPRBC for his 
entire hospital course. Thought to be a combination of 
phlebotomy, malnutrition, and depressed marrow response. His Hb 
stable for numerous days at discharge.

# Acute Oliguric Renal Failure ___ ATN
# Volume overload: 
With creatinine to a peak of 5.1. Thought to be due to a 
combination of prerenal insult -> ATN as well as volume 
overload. Pt briefly required two sessions of hemodialysis due 
to oliguria, but as his urine output improved and his creatinine 
downtrended his dialysis was discontinued. A tunneled subclavian 
dialysis catheter also removed at this time. For volume 
overload, Pt initially required BID IV furosemide diuresis; this 
was transitioned to 40mg PO furosemide and 50mg spironolactone 
daily when more euvolemic. He was without oxygen requirement at 
discharge, and his discharge creatinine was 0.9.
- Prescribed additional daily supplementation with 20mEq K and 
400mg mag oxide BID given ongoing electrolyte losses.

# Hypoxia:
# Fluid overload/Pulmonary Edema: 
In the setting of infected hepatic hydrothorax, as well as 
volume overload as above. Improved to room air after treatment 
of infection, daily drainage through TPC, and IV diuresis. He 
was maintained on PO furosemide and spironolactone at discharge, 
with electrolyte supplementation as above.

#Sepsis/hypotension 
BP low at baseline given ESLD. Initially required midodrine in 
the setting of acute kidney injury; this was decreased to 2.5mg 
TID and then discontinued upon discharge. BP improved with 
control of infection.

# NASH Cirrhosis c/b varices, HE, hepatic hydrothorax s/p TIPS: 
Pt was on transplant list, activated during the acuity of his 
illness. MELD-Na 25 at admission with subsequent peak of 40, now 
improving with above measures.
- Home PO vitamin K
- Home rifaximin and lactulose
- Augmentin as above for active infection

# GERD: 
- Home PPI

# Cough 
- Tessalon pearls 

# T2DM: 
- Given insulin sliding scale while at home. 
- Transitional issue to give dietary counseling and consider 
metformin at home, given blood sugars in the high 100-200 range 
while in-house.

# Left shoulder pain: 
Chronic and worse with use. Resolved today. MSK vs visceral 
though MSK more likely. 
- Given acetaminophen PRN

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure caring for you at the ___ 
___.  

You were seen in our hospital because you were having worsening 
leg swelling, nausea, and vomiting blood.  Based on your imaging 
and other blood tests, we found that you had a bad infection 
from some fluid that built up around your lung.  You initially 
went to our Intensive Care Unit, where we gave you fluids and 
medicines to keep your blood pressure up.  You also had a tube 
placed in your right chest to help remove some of that infected 
fluid, which helped with your trouble breathing.  We continued 
to treat the infection with antibiotics and drain of the 
infected fluid.  When the infected fluid stopped accumulating, 
we were able to remove the drain in your chest.

Your kidneys also began to show evidence of damage during this 
time.  We thought this was due to your ongoing infection, as 
well as having a lot of fluid in your legs and lungs.  We gave 
you medicines to help get rid of this water, as well as treating 
your infection.  These helped your kidneys return to normal 
functioning levels.

Because you were so sick, you were put on the liver transplant 
list again.  Please talk to your liver doctor to find out what 
the next steps are in your transplant waiting time.

We did make some changes to your medications. We increased your 
furosemide and your spironolactone. You will also need to take 
an antibiotic called amoxicillin-clavulanic acid. This is for 
treatment of your lung infection. You should take this until 
___. On ___, you will need to start taking 
ciprofloxacin. This antibiotic will help to prevent further 
infections. We have also started you on metoclopramide to help 
with nausea. Only take this medication if you need it. We have 
also started you on magnesium oxide and potassium chloride to 
help with the salts in your blood. 

We wish you the best,
Your ___ Care Team

¿Qué es un ___ pleural? Un ___ pleural es un líquido 
lleno de pus ___ pleural a causa de una infección. ___ 
___ pleural está entre sus pulmones y el interior ___ 
___ torácica. El ___ pleural usualmente es provocado por 
una neumonía. Puede llegar a ser una emergencia médica que 
requiere tratamiento inmediato.

¿Cómo se trata un ___ pleural? 
Antibióticos usualmente son ___ para ___ una 
infección bacteriana. Este medicamento se administra para ___ 
___ neumonía. Es posible que a usted no ___ 
antibióticos ___ no es a causa de ___ neumonía.

Un drenaje o tubo torácico podría ser colocado para extraer 
líquido ___ pleural.

Toracotomía es un procedimiento que se usa para drenar líquido 
alrededor de sus pulmones y eliminar el pus y cualquier 
cicatrización. ___ médico más información sobre este 
procedimiento. 

Cirugía podría usarse para ayudar a que sus pulmones se 
expandan más fácilmente y por completo.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to the inpatient Colorectal Surgery 
Serivce post-operatively/ His post-operative check was stable. 
He was given intravenous fluids for hydration.  On his diet was 
sips of fluids only given his extensive lysis of adhesions and  
two anastomoses. We continued intravenous hydration. On the 
morning os post-operative day one he was doing quite well. He 
tolerated a small amount of clear liquids. He was noted to be 
tremulous with ambulation. All vital signs were stable and he 
had no other symptoms. He reported he had previously had similar 
symptoms when given narcotic pain medication after joint 
replacement surgery. This was improved at rest. Reglan was 
discontinued as a precaution. The Foley catheter was removed at 
midline and he voided without issue. The following day, he was 
doing well in the morning however, in the late morning he 
reported having nausea and had one episode of emesis. 
Intravenous hydration was continued and he was NPO. He passed 
flatus. In the afternoon he was noted to be febrile to 101 and 
he reported feeling week. OK dressing was taken down and the 
incision was intact. He was rigorous. He moved his bowels, his 
stool was black. EKG showed sinus tachycardia, cardiac enzymes 
were sent as a precaution and were negative. His urinalysis was 
negative.  He had acute onset of abdominal pain and was feeling 
unwell. He was evaluated by the chief resident and surgical 
attending. Broad spectrum antibiotic therapy was started out of 
concern for a leak. No leak or small bowel injury was found in 
the operating room. Howervern he did have very distended loops 
of small ___ and a nasogastric tube was left in place. A JP 
drain was left in place. Postoperatively the patient had a fever 
to 102.5, repeat chest film showed NG tube tip as in the stomach 
and interval increase in perihilar and basal opacities, 
concerning for interval 
aspiration or potentially increase in pleural effusion.  
Pneumonia was seen as unlikely. Over the next few days, he began 
to improve. The nasogastric tube was removed and the antibiotic 
therapy was transitioned to oral antibiotics. He was then 
tolerating a regular diet. He was discharged home on ___.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Adhesive disease and Crohn's ileitis.
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after a Extensive lysis of 
adhesions and ileocolectomy for surgical management of your 
Crohns Disease. Unfortunately after surgery you became acutely 
sick and you were taking to the operating room again for an 
exploratory laparotomy to be sure nothing was leaking from the 
surgery however this was negative. You have recovered from this 
procedure well and you are now ready to return home. Samples 
from your bowel were taken and this tissue has been sent to the 
pathology department for analysis. You will receive these 
pathology results at your follow-up appointment. If there is an 
urgent need for the surgeon to contact you regarding these 
results they will contact you before this time. You have 
tolerated a regular diet, passing gas and your pain is 
controlled with pain medications by mouth. You may return home 
to finish your recovery. You will need to continue to take the 
antibiotic Amoxicillin  until ___. This is treating a 
pneumonia. 
 
Please monitor your bowel function closely. You may or may not 
have had a bowel movement prior to your discharge which is 
acceptable, however it is important that you have a bowel 
movement in the next ___ days. After anesthesia it is not 
uncommon for patients to have some decrease in bowel function 
but you should not have prolonged constipation. Some loose stool 
and passing of small amounts of dark, old appearing blood are 
expected. However, if you notice that you are passing bright red 
blood with bowel movements or having loose stool without 
improvement please call the office or go to the emergency room 
if the symptoms are severe. If you are taking narcotic pain 
medications there is a risk that you will have some 
constipation. Please take an over the counter stool softener 
such as Colace, and if the symptoms do not improve call the 
office. If you have any of the following symptoms please call 
the office for advice or go to the emergency room if severe: 
increasing abdominal distension, increasing abdominal pain, 
nausea, vomiting, inability to tolerate food or liquids, 
prolonged loose stool, or extended constipation.  
 
You have a long vertical incision on your abdomen that is closed 
with staples and a VAC suction dressing. The staples will stay 
in place until your first post-operative visit at which time 
they can be removed in the clinic, most likely by the office 
nurse. THe VAC dressing should be removed every three days. The 
VAC dressing should always be to suction. If the VAC machiene is 
alarming please call the visiting nurses and our office. Please 
monitor the incision for signs and symptoms of infection 
including: increasing redness at the incision, opening of the 
incision, increased pain at the incision line, draining of 
white/green/yellow/foul smelling drainage, or if you develop a 
fever. Please call the office if you develop these symptoms or 
go to the emergency room if the symptoms are severe. You may 
shower, let the warm water run over the incision line and pat 
the area dry with a towel, do not rub. The visiting nurses ___ 
change the VAC dressing.   
 
No heavy lifting for at least 6 weeks after surgery unless 
instructed otherwise by your surgical team. You may gradually 
increase your activity as tolerated but clear heavy exercise 
with your surgical team.  
 
You may take Tylenol as recommended for pain. Please do not take 
more than 4000mg of Tylenol daily. Do not drink alcohol while 
taking narcotic pain medication or Tylenol. Please do not drive 
a car while taking narcotic pain medication.  
 
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care! Our hope 
is that you will have a quick return to your life and usual 
activities. Good luck!  

 
Followup Instructions:
___
